title: Covering space
summary: In mathematics, specifically algebraic topology, a covering map (also covering projection) is a continuous function p {\displaystyle p} from a topological space C {\displaystyle C} to a topological space X {\displaystyle X} such that each point in X {\displaystyle X} has an open neighborhood evenly covered by p {\displaystyle p} (as shown in the image).[1] In this case, C {\displaystyle C} is called a covering space and X {\displaystyle X} the base space of the covering projection. The definition implies that every covering map is a local homeomorphism.
